channel.title: Planet Money but it's all episodes
channel.description: NPR's Planet Money. The economy, explained. Collated into a full-history feed by /u/xjcl.

item.title: Day of the Debt
item.description: We make a loan to the U.S. government, and it does not go the way we thought it would. Plus: the story of that one time the U.S. defaulted. Subscribe to our weekly newsletter here.
item.copyright: Copyright 2015-2021 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: You asked for real raises, free shipping, and a special delivery
item.description: It's listener question time. We've got answers about "free" shipping, full employment, when a raise isn't a raise, Taylor Swift, crypto seizures and our very own Micro-Face comic. | Subscribe to our weekly newsletter here.

item.title: A trunk full of truffles (Update)
item.description: Truffles are one of the most expensive and sought after ingredients in the world. Today, we look back at our NYC adventure with a truffle smuggler and how the market has changed since we last talked to him. | Subscribe to our weekly newsletter here.

item.title: Of boats and boxes
item.description: We take a trip to ports on the east and west coasts to ask what's on everyone's mind: why are they so clogged? And how can we fix it? | Subscribe to our weekly newsletter here.

item.title: Auction fever (Classic)

item.title: Burnout (Classic)
item.description: All types of companies are struggling with burnout. Many try to fix it. Most of them fail. One exception: A 26-year-old call center manager, with stress balls and costumes in her arsenal. | Subscribe to our weekly newsletter here.

item.title: Bonus: Janet Jackson's 'Control'
item.description: On the 35th anniversary of Janet Jackson's first No. 1 Billboard Hot 100 hit, our friends at It's Been A Minute look back at Control, her career-defining album that changed the trajectory of pop music in the late '80s and '90s.
item.copyright: Copyright 2015-2021 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.description: Noncompete agreements have become an integral part of job contracts. A show about what they are and how we got here. | Subscribe to our weekly newsletter here.

item.title: How Do You Feel? (Classic)
item.description: We tend to think of economists as cold, unfeeling, attempting to be as rational as possible. But once a month, economists pick up the phone to just... check in with us. How are we feeling? Good, bad, worse than a year ago? It's a very specific phone call with very specific questions and a few years ago we looked into the origins of this very important survey that factors into economic decision making. | Subscribe to our weekly newsletter here.
item.copyright: Copyright 2015-2021 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: LIBOR pains
item.description: For decades, banks used one rate to help set all other rates: LIBOR. After it came out that it'd been rigged, regulators said: no more. Now it's a race — and a road trip — to find an alternative. | Subscribe to our weekly newsletter here.
item.copyright: Copyright 2015-2021 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Two Indicators: Women And Work
item.description: Women start a lot of businesses, but when it comes time for them to grow, many hit a wall, or the women founders end up losing control. Why? We bring you two indicators on women and work from our daily podcast The Indicator. Also, Amanda and Stacey go on a picnic to prove a point. | Subscribe to our weekly newsletter here.

item.title: Two Indicators: Water Pressure

item.title: SUMMER SCHOOL 6: Crypto & Commencement
item.description: In the last class of Planet Money Summer School Season 2, we cover one more important market — cryptocurrency. If you're thinking about investing in crypto, do you know exactly what it is that you're buying? Or how it should (if at all) fit alongside the rest of your investments? | Watch this Tik Tok to learn more and subscribe to our weekly newsletter here. | Don't forget to take the Summer School Final Quiz.

item.title: The Lost Archives of Sadie Alexander
item.description: The work of our first Black economist was lost to history. Professor Nina Banks set out on a quest to find it. | Subscribe to our weekly newsletter here.
item.copyright: Copyright 2015-2021 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: SUMMER SCHOOL 5: Bubbles, Bikes, & Biases
item.description: Investing during a bubble can leave you bust. But how to tell the difference between a bubble before it bursts and an investing rocket ship taking off? We'll run through a historical example and look inside our own thinking to find the mental biases that can contribute or exacerbate bad bubble thinking. | Watch this Tik Tok to learn more and subscribe to our weekly newsletter here.

item.title: Two Indicators: Will Remote Work Kill The Office?
item.description: It's Stacey vs Greg in a face off on the future of the office. Each takes a side, armed with studies, historical examples, theories on efficiency and happiness and from their closet studios, they bring their indicators for the future of the office. | Subscribe to our weekly newsletter here. And our daily podcast The Indicator hosted by Stacey here.

item.title: SUMMER SCHOOL 4: Bonds & Becky With The Good Yield
item.description: A few years back, Cardiff asked for an unusual Christmas present: a junk bond... Parallel to the stock market, the bond market offers different levels of risk and reward. In this class, what is a bond, how do they differ from stocks, and how do they help companies grow? | Watch this Tik Tok to learn more and subscribe to our weekly newsletter here.

item.description: There are a lot of fancy terms for the things we experience — but are they really useful? Yes! We explain four social-science terms that can help us understand our world. | Subscribe to our weekly newsletter here.

item.title: SUMMER SCHOOL 3: Smooth Spending & The 401K
item.description: Even if you don't own stocks, there are a lot of reasons to care about investing. We meet some of the folks left out of the stock market who deploy sophisticated economic thinking, even creating their own alternate financial systems. Our professors help us understand how consumption smoothing and life-cycle hypothesis apply to personal finance. And we meet the creator of the 401(k). | Watch this Tik Tok to learn more and subscribe to our weekly newsletter here.

item.title: Mobile Home Parked
item.description: We find out what happens when big investors spend billions of dollars buying mobile home parks and make them less affordable for the people who live there. Then we learn how the government helps them do it, with super low-cost loans that were meant to support affordable housing. | Subscribe to our weekly newsletter here.

item.title: SUMMER SCHOOL 2: Index Funds & The Bet
item.description: In 2006, Warren Buffett bet a million dollars that the most brainless, boring investment around would do better than the researched, handpicked investments of some of the smartest hedge fund managers in the world. The second class of Summer School looks at how that bet played out, the origins of the index fund, and why it's so hard to beat the market. Returning to the underlying theme of risk and reward, we also discuss how diversification reduces risk. | Watch this Tik Tok to learn more and subscribe to our weekly newsletter here.

item.title: SUMMER SCHOOL 1: The Stock Market & Penelope The Cow
item.description: The first class of Planet Money Summer School starts off with a field trip. With the help of a cow, two economists, and three cute animals, we learn what a stock is and how stocks are priced, and we begin to see the psychological forces that make prices move up and down on the stock market. Keep an eye out throughout for our big theme for the course this summer: risk and reward. | Watch this Tik Tok to learn more and subscribe to our weekly newsletter here.

item.title: 100 Years Since Sadie Alexander
item.description: In 1921, Sadie Alexander became the first Black person in America to receive a PhD in economics. Then, she was functionally shut out of economics jobs, got a law degree, and became an attorney instead. A century later, economics has made notably little progress bringing Black women into the field. We work with The Sadie Collective to bring you three stories from three eras of recent history that show us how the field has changed, where it still falls short, and the unique joys of being a Black woman and loving economics. | Subscribe to our weekly newsletter here.
item.copyright: Copyright 2015-2021 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Planet Money Summer School
item.description: Introducing an economics education for your ears! We're calling it Planet Money Summer School. It's all the economics you meant to learn, but didn't get around to. Each Wednesday, we'll serve up a Planet Money story, or selection of excerpts, paired with insights from our economists-in-residence for the summer. Get an understanding of the basic concepts of economics going to the beach. You can pick up your economics knowledge while you bike, stroll the sand or just lay in the grass. Amuse your friends. Win arguments. Throw the words "diminishing marginal utility" into every discussion. Wednesdays in the PM feed this summer. (Fridays will be our usual coverage of the economy). Start listening to the episodes here.

item.itunes:title: The Day Of Two Noons
item.itunes:author: NPR
item.itunes:summary: In the 1800s, every town had its own "local time," which was not only confusing, but sometimes dangerous. So railroads implemented the standardized time we have today.
item.itunes:subtitle: In the 1800s, every town had its own "local time," which was not only confusing, but sometimes dangerous. So railroads implemented the standardized time we have today.
item.content:encoded: People didn't always know what time it was. But in the nineteenth century, a high school principal, a scientist, and a railroad bureaucrat synchronized the nation.

item.title: #651: The Salmon Taboo
item.description: In Japan, salmon used to be garbage fish. Today, it's a delicacy. How one Norwegian with a lot of extra fish changed the tastes of a nation.
item.copyright: Copyright 2015-2020 NPR - For Personal Use Only
item.itunes:title: The Salmon Taboo
item.itunes:author: NPR
item.itunes:summary: People in Japan never ate raw salmon. Then Norway had a salmon surplus—and persuaded Japanese sushi eaters to try something new.
item.itunes:subtitle: People in Japan never ate raw salmon. Then Norway had a salmon surplus—and persuaded Japanese sushi eaters to try something new.
item.content:encoded: In Japan, salmon used to be garbage fish. Today, it's a delicacy. How one Norwegian with a lot of extra fish changed the tastes of a nation.

item.title: #917: Quit Threat!
item.description: Sometimes an economy can get so strong the power dynamic between bosses and workers flips: Full employment. Are we there yet?
item.copyright: Copyright 2015-2020 NPR - For Personal Use Only
item.itunes:title: Quit Threat!
item.itunes:author: NPR
item.itunes:summary: The unemployment rate in the U.S. is just 3.6%. Many people think we are at, or near, full employment. For the first time in a long while, power is shifting toward workers.
item.itunes:subtitle: The unemployment rate in the U.S. is just 3.6%. Many people think we are at, or near, full employment. For the first time in a long while, power is shifting toward workers.
item.content:encoded: Sometimes an economy can get so strong the power dynamic between bosses and workers flips: Full employment. Are we there yet?

item.title: #916: The Whistleblower Whisperer
item.description: Jordan Thomas is a lawyer who represents some of Wall Street's biggest whistleblowers. The life that led him here is extraordinary.
item.copyright: Copyright 2015-2020 NPR - For Personal Use Only
item.itunes:title: The Whistleblower Whisperer
item.itunes:author: NPR
item.itunes:summary: Jordan Thomas represents Wall Street whistleblowers in some of the biggest SEC cases against banks. In addition to protecting their secrets, he's also kept some of his own.
item.itunes:subtitle: Jordan Thomas represents Wall Street whistleblowers in some of the biggest SEC cases against banks. In addition to protecting their secrets, he's also kept some of his own.
item.content:encoded: Jordan Thomas is a lawyer who represents some of Wall Street's biggest whistleblowers. The life that led him here is extraordinary.

item.title: #915: How To Meddle In An Election
item.description: In which someone runs a science experiment on an actual election, on actual voters, to test the persuasive power of ethically sketchy methods.
item.copyright: Copyright 2015-2020 NPR - For Personal Use Only
item.itunes:title: How To Meddle In An Election
item.itunes:author: NPR
item.itunes:summary: David Goldstein decides to copy Cambridge Analytica and run an experiment on actual voters during the 2017 Alabama special election.
item.itunes:subtitle: David Goldstein decides to copy Cambridge Analytica and run an experiment on actual voters during the 2017 Alabama special election.
item.content:encoded: In which someone runs a science experiment on an actual election, on actual voters, to test the persuasive power of ethically sketchy methods.

item.description: After Donald Trump's companies declared four bankruptcies, several major banks stopped loaning him money. But Deutsche Bank didn't.

item.description: The story of an innovation that changed the way the world works, and of the man who made this innovation possible: Luca Pacioli.

item.itunes:subtitle: The story of Luca Pacioli, who brought double-entry bookkeeping to the masses, transforming accounting and businesses around the world.

item.title: #911: You Asked The Listener Question Hotline
item.description: We answer a bunch of the questions you asked — and even one you *didn't* ask.

item.itunes:title: You Asked The Listener Question Hotline

item.title: #416: Why The Price of Coke Didn't Change For 70 years
item.description: For 70 years, the price of a bottle of Coca-Cola stayed a nickel. Why? The answer includes a half a million vending machines and a 7.5 cent coin.
item.copyright: Copyright 2015-2020 NPR - For Personal Use Only
item.itunes:title: Why The Price of Coke Didn't Change For 70 years

item.itunes:summary: For 70 years, the price of a bottle of Coca-Cola stayed a nickel. Why? The answer includes a half a million vending machines and a 7.5 cent coin.

item.description: Dollar General, Dollar Tree and Family Dollar are opening up stores every six hours around the country. Some towns are fighting them.
item.title: #909: Dollar Stores Vs Lettuce

item.description: The remarkable story of the online CAPTCHA tests we've all taken to stop spam and prove we're not robots.
item.title: #908: I Am Not A Robot

item.description: A trade war with China—and a hurricane—make peanut farmers miserable. And we look at the World Happiness Report for 2018.
item.title: #907: Two Spring Indicators

item.description: The wisdom of crowds is an eerie phenomenon that informs everything from the stock market to the price of orange juice. We put it to the test with a farm animal.
item.title: #644: How Much Does This Cow Weigh?

item.description: In 1973, a coup took Chile from socialism to capitalism. That economic shift was implemented by a ruthless dictator with the help of a handful of economists known as the Chicago Boys.
item.title: #906: The Chicago Boys, Part II

item.description: Today Chile has one of the wealthiest, most stable economies in South America. But it was born in a violent struggle, between Marxism and capitalism, democracy and dictatorship.
item.title: #905: The Chicago Boys, Part I

item.description: We follow the founder of f*ckjerry and comedian Jim Mendrinos into the world of comedy. Where a whole series of informal sanctions are deployed to protect jokes from theft.
item.title: #904: Joke Theft

item.description: Joe Bankman, professor at Stanford, figured out a way to make filing your taxes easy and painless. Then the tax lobby found out about it.
item.title: #760: Tax Hero

item.description: Some colleges are offering students a new way to pay. It's not a scholarship. It's not a loan. It's called an income share agreement. It's like the students are selling stock in themselves.
item.title: #903: A New Way To Pay For College

item.description: The story behind two sneaky forces that drive us to buy more products, more often: Planned obsolescence and psychological obsolescence.
item.title: #902: The Phoebus Cartel

item.description: There's an entire, powerful industry pushing behind the scenes for better police behavior--not with protests or picket signs, but spreadsheets and actuaries.
item.title: #901: Bad Cops Are Expensive

item.description: Today's show is about the fickle market for art. What makes a dead shark cost $12 million, and a photo of steel wool that looks like a tornado cost only $1,265?
item.title: #189: Why A Dead Shark Costs $12 Million

item.description: When an American company named ABRO learns their goods are being counterfeited in China, they pursue lawsuits, extraditions, sting operations and more to make it stop.
item.title: #900: The Stolen Company

item.description: The internet was supposed to get rid of middlemen--but instead there are more than ever. Today on the show, we look into how one sneaky strategy, dropship arbitrage, is taking over Amazon and Ebay.
item.title: #724: Cat Scam

item.description: Cartels in Mexico aren't just trafficking in drugs anymore; they're also stealing fuel. The Mexican Government is taking action to cut them off. But it's costing a lot of money, and lives.
item.title: #899: Mexico Fights The Fuel Pirates

item.description: The Starbury shoe was affordable and endorsed by NBA All-Star Stephon Marbury. The big challenge was convincing the world that a cheap sneaker wasn't a crappy sneaker.
item.title: #785: The Starbury

item.description: How the Federal Reserve won its independence, and then held on during an attack—a physical attack—by the President of the United States.
item.title: #898: Happy Fed Independence Day

item.description: New Orleans has become a battleground for Airbnb. Preservationists want to save the city. Landlords want to open it up. Can either win without destroying the other?
item.title: #897: New Orleans Vs. Airbnb

item.description: A three-part series on the history of competition, big business, and antitrust law, one of the most important but least-understood bodies of law in the United States.
item.title: #896: Antitrust 3: Big Tech

item.description: How Robert Bork won the fight over antitrust law, changed the meaning of competition in America, and paved the way for some of the biggest companies we've ever seen.
item.title: #895: Antitrust 2: The Paradox

item.description: At the turn of the 20th century, Ida Tarbell investigated John D. Rockefeller's Standard Oil. What she discovered changed the economy of the United States.
item.title: #894: Antitrust 1: Standard Oil

item.description: To catch drug traffickers, the U.S. government tried something it had never tried before. It set up and ran a fake offshore bank for money laundering. Fake name. Fake employees. Real drug money.
item.title: #418: A Fake Bank For Money Laundering Run By The Government

item.description: We're back for our annual tradition: Channeling another year's worth of jealousy and self-loathing into a whole episode just for you. Happy Valentine's Day!
item.title: #893: Our Valentines 2019

item.description: On today's show, we follow a commercial flight that made an emergency landing in Iran last December. And we discover that landing in Iran would be easy. Getting out – much, much harder.
item.title: #892: The Lost Plane

item.description: On today's show we answer questions about silver dollars, Venmo, and Brexit. Why? Because you asked!
item.title: #887: You Asked For It, Yet Again

item.description: Five years ago Ben Horowitz and Felix Salmon placed a bet about the future of bitcoin. Today we announce the winner.
item.title: #891: Who Won The Bet Over Bitcoin?

item.description: After a wildfire, teams of investigators start combing the wreckage for clues. Finding the cause means, maybe, finding someone to pay. But where's the line between a natural disaster and a human one?
item.title: #825: Who Started The Wildfire?

item.description: We go to a harbor in Santa Barbara where the wait for a spot to park your boat used to be as long as 200 years. Today on the show, we're on a mission to figure out how to divide resources fairly.
item.title: #890: The Division Problem

item.description: John Bogle died last week. His creation — the index fund — changed investing. Today, how his invention set off a million dollar bet between some of the biggest brains on Wall Street.
item.title: #688: Brilliant Vs. Boring

item.description: In 2010, Panera launched several pay-what-you-want cafes. On today's show: We talk to Panera founder Ron Shaich about how this turned out.
item.title: #889: The Pay-What-You-Want Experiment

item.description: In 1879, Congress and the President were locked in a battle over the rights of African-Americans. It led to the first government shutdown.
item.title: #888: The First Shutdown

item.description: On today's show we answer questions about silver dollars, Venmo, and Brexit. Why? Because you asked!
item.title: #887: You Asked For It, Yet Again

item.description: We go inside a professional poker tournament. It turns out some of the smartest players aren't just betting on themselves, but are actually staking their competition.
item.title: #690: All In

item.description: Hackers are an expensive headache for companies. But there might be a simple economic fix.
item.title: #886: The Price of a Hack

item.description: People are the engine that fuels an economy. But what happens when you start running out of people?
item.title: #885: Do It For Your Country

item.description: We check in on some stories we did this year to find all kinds of updates.
item.title: #884: The Rest Of The Story, Winter 2018

item.description: How the card game Magic: The Gathering deflated a speculative bubble.
item.title: #609: The Curse Of The Black Lotus

item.description: Charles Dickens wanted to pick a fight with economists. So he invented Ebenezer Scrooge. But did he get it right?
item.title: #883: A Very Planet Money Christmas Carol

item.description: Synthetic drugs like "Spice" and "K2" have helped jumpstart a revolution in the drug trade.
item.title: #882: Synthetic Reefer Madness

item.description: A truce in the U.S.-China trade war seemed close. And then the arrests started.
item.title: #881: The Prisoners of the Trade War

item.description: We try to figure out what makes cents.
item.title: #539: What's A Penny Worth?

item.description: Amazon is opening a new office in Long Island City, Queens. Critics of the plan say New York got ripped off from a big corporation. We spent a day in the neighborhood asking people what they think.
item.title: #880: Is Amazon Good For New York?

item.description: The U.S. and Europe just can't agree on car safety standards. That puts car companies in a weird position, makes car cost more and just seems kind of random and wasteful.
item.title: #533: Why Car Safety Is A Trade Barrier

item.description: The Federal Reserve spends a lot of effort trying to target the level of inflation to about 2 percent. Why? Because tiny New Zealand did it first.
item.title: #879: The Secret Target

item.description: We talk to Kid Rock about how he tried to cut scalpers out of the business, then compare that to what Taylor Swift did.
item.title: #468: Kid Rock Vs. The Scalpers

item.description: We go deep inside the market for mugshots. Is it extortion? Or is it a First Amendment right?
item.title: #878: Mugshots For Sale

item.description: Parkinson's Law says work expands to fill the time allotted. Goodhart's Law says you get what you measure. Has anyone ever tested these laws of the modern workplace?
item.title: #877: The Laws of The Office

item.description: New York, Washington and dozens of other cities threw billions in tax incentives at Amazon's HQ2. It reminded us of an episode we did back in 2016.
item.title: #699: Kansas City Vs. Kansas City

item.description: Matthew Whitaker, the acting attorney general, sat on an advisory board of World Patent Marketing. Now the company is being called a scam.
item.title: #876: Patent Deception

item.description: The market for beef explains a lot about what works about the relationship between Mexico and the U.S.
item.title: #875: Why Did The Cow Cross The Border?

item.description: The Falcons are trying something radical: Making their food cheaper. It could break stadium economics.
item.title: #874: Hot Dog Hail Mary

item.description: Seattle's radical solution to big money in politics: Flood elections with even more money.
item.title: #873: The Seattle Experiment

item.description: Two reporters walk into a haunted house, in this special Halloween episode.
item.title: #872: The Halloween Tapes

item.description: China is trying a bold experiment to help people trust each other more: The social credit score. Will it work? Does it go too far?
item.title: #871: Blacklisted In China

item.description: The first lottery was a royal affair with poems, golden flatware and invited criminals. Also, how someone won the lottery over and over.
item.title: #676: The First Lottery & How To Beat The Odds

item.description: President Trump promised to slash regulations. How has he done?
item.title: #870: Trump vs. Red Tape

item.description: We try to tell the difference between correlation and causation.
item.title: #453: What Causes What?

item.description: Seth Frotman worked overseeing student loans for the government. He saw things that made him quit.
item.title: #869: The Student Loan Whistleblower

item.description: Bill Nordhaus just won the economics Nobel. In this show: He shows how history of light is the history of economic growth — of things getting faster, cheaper, and more efficient.
item.title: #534: The History of Light (Nobel Edition)

item.description: We follow writer Oliver Bullough as he explores how stolen money moves around the world, and what that might mean for democracies.
item.title: #868: Moneyland

item.description: You've seen these ads: "You can work from home and get rich. It's easy. Call this number!" So, what happens when you respond?
item.title: #680: Anatomy Of A Scam

item.description: We tell the story of a massive crackdown on asylum fraud, and the fallout.
item.title: #867: Special Report: Asylum Crackdown

item.description: In 2012, a Justice Department probe shut down law firms that helped Chinese asylum-seekers fabricate or inflate claims of persecution. The clients were left alone, but now 13,500 may have to leave.
item.title: 'The Souls Of China' Documents Country's Dramatic Return To Religion

item.description: We rethink everything we know about government spending, taxes, the nature of money... All of it.
item.title: #866: Modern Monetary Theory

item.description: We propose small fixes for baseball, weddings, salary negotiations and buying your morning coffee. Warning: They may be too rational.
item.title: #865: Tweak This

item.description: How one man took the onion market hostage.
item.title: #657: The Tale Of The Onion King

item.description: We crash a party of central bankers to get an answer to one of the biggest economic questions of our time.
item.title: #864: The Central (Bankers') Question

item.description: In honor of our 10th anniversary, we revisit our very first episode.
item.title: For Our 10th Anniversary, Episode #1

item.description: What a hole-in-one gone awry says about the state of charity.
item.title: #863: The 13th Hole

item.description: Subaru's sales had been slumping for years. Then they went straight to their biggest fans: Lesbians.
item.title: #729: When Subaru Came Out

item.description: That time we accidentally created a cheese surplus so large it had to be stored in a ginormous cave.
item.title: #862: Big Government Cheese

item.description: California just did away with cash bail. But credit where credit is due. New Jersey already tried something similar.
item.title: #783: New Jersey Bails Out

item.description: When food makes people sick all around the country, an army of germ detectives jumps into action.
item.title: #861: Food Scare Squad

item.description: Today on the show: Could New Jersey become the next Napa?
item.title: #444: New Jersey Wine

item.description: Six states. Three days. One ugly cookie jar. Today on the show: Yard sale!
item.title: #860: The World's Longest Yard Sale

item.description: The line between trash and recycling is moving a lot these days. It's a tough time to be a recycler.
item.title: #613: Trash!

item.description: You have a lot of questions... about tariffs, unemployment rates, and RV dealerships, to name a few. We have answers.
item.title: #859: You Asked For Even More

item.description: This episode is for everyone who ever had to ask their coworkers to quiet down. Today on the show: We meet the man who stole your office door.
item.title: #704: Open Office

item.description: The Venezuelan government doesn't want you to know the real value of its currency. But Ruben and Mila figured it out. Now they're on the lam.
item.title: #858: Venezuela's Fugitive Money Traders

item.description: Is there a secretive postal organization fixing international shipping rates, and giving American businesses a bad deal?
item.title: #857: The Postal Illuminati

item.description: There's a simple way to solve the housing crisis in U.S. cities. Only problem is, almost everybody hates it.
item.title: #856: Yes In My Backyard

item.description: What happens when a group of economists applies the number one rule of economics... to number two?
item.title: #855: The Poop Cartel

item.description: Socialism was political poison in the U.S. for decades. Now it's gaining ground. Who are these new socialists? And what do they want?
item.title: #854: The New Socialists

item.description: Tax carbon emissions. That's basically the whole plan. What's the hold up?
item.title: #472: The One-Page Plan To Fix Global Warming Revisited

item.description: Sand. It's in buildings, windows, your cell phone. But there isn't enough in the world for everyone. And that's created a dangerous black market.
item.title: #853: Peak Sand

item.description: LeBron James is getting hosed. The NBA team owners, the players, the fans and even LeBron James himself want to keep it that way.
item.title: #427: LeBron James Is Still Underpaid

item.description: Two stories from our Indicator team. One province in China makes many of the world's flags. It's a unique window on global trade. And we find out why so few teenagers are working summer jobs.
item.title: #852: Two Summer Indicators

item.description: It takes strategy and skill to sell snacks at a baseball game. Meet the hot dog vending legend of Fenway Park.
item.title: #700: Peanuts And Cracker Jack

item.description: A pesticide wreaks havoc. A listener needs a bitcoin detective. And the search for the rarest economic good continues.
item.title: #851: The Rest Of The Story Summer 2018

item.description: Fake product reviews are wrecking the internet. But help is on the way: From a bodybuilding fake review hunter.
item.title: #850: The Fake Review Hunter

item.description: Politicians have argued for decades that CEOs are overpaid. But there's this precise moment in the 1990s when CEO pay suddenly shot up. We find out what happened.
item.title: #682: When CEO Pay Exploded

item.description: President Trump says China is stealing U.S. technology. So we looked into one case. And things got a little complicated.
item.title: #849: It Takes Two To Make A Trade War Fight

item.description: California has a ton of solar power. But as soon as night falls, it's gone. Today on the show: How to bottle the sun.
item.title: #848: The World's Biggest Battery

item.description: The medical world has been trying to cure color blindness for centuries. Then a glass scientist figured it out. By accident.
item.title: #847: Inventing Accidents

item.description: When Florida outlawed partisan gerrymandering, politicians tried to sneak it back in ... in disguise.
item.title: #846: Ungerrymandering Florida

item.description: Meet Sue, the dinosaur who sparked a gold rush for fossils buried in the badlands of North Dakota, Wyoming, and Montana.
item.title: #660: The T-Rex In My Backyard

item.description: Meet the man who figured out how to reshape national politics by making tiny investments in the smallest of places.
item.title: #845: REDMAP

item.description: In game theory, sometimes the best way to win, is to lose.
item.title: #844: Nice Game

item.description: Today on the show: A small town stakes its future on writing, directing, and starring in a musical.
item.title: #843: Swamp Gravy

item.description: Gene Freidman built a taxi empire. We visited him before he was in legal trouble.
item.title: #643: The Taxi King

item.description: The World Trade Organization: Can't live with it, hard to crush your trade opponents without it.
item.title: #842: Showdown at the WTO

item.description: Class actions run from big civil rights cases to arguments about pepper. Are they noble, or silly?
item.title: #696: Class Action

item.description: We meet the man who invented duty free shopping and find out if these tax free stores are really saving us any money.
item.title: #841: The Land Of Duty Free

item.description: Today on the show: A chicken index, some Wall Street investors, and an unlikely whistle-blower.
item.title: #840: Fixing Chicken

item.description: California is way more than Hollywood. Today on the show, we look at what else is going on in this powerhouse state economy.
item.title: #839: The Indicator Goes To California

item.description: Today on the show: How a cheese cartel abandoned the rules of economics and convinced the world to eat fondue.
item.title: #575: The Fondue Conspiracy

item.description: Unordered trinkets have been arriving at homes around the country. We try to find out why.
item.title: #838: A Series of Mysterious Packages

item.description: Today on the show: the economics of drought, and why the rational thing to do in California right now is use more water.
item.title: #640: The Bottom Of The Well

item.description: Today on the show, we connect the dots between New York, Uganda, Prague, and China's thirst for resources.
item.title: #837: The Belt, The Road And The Money

item.description: Why are used car commercials so annoying? Meet the original sinner.
item.title: #836: The Rational Madness Of The Used Car Salesman

item.description: We're in a full-fledged trade war with China. We dig into the list of Chinese tariffs on American products. It gets weird...and delicious.
item.title: #835: Tariffied

item.description: Today on the show: how an economic fix helped made the deadliest job in America safer, and why people are angry about it.
item.title: #661: The Less Deadly Catch

item.description: Today on the show, we talk to one of the most famous NDA breakers of all time, and ask: If you've made an agreement like that, is there a legal way out?
item.title: #834: NDA Tell-All

item.description: What exactly would happen if you didn't pay your taxes? Today on the show, we follow one man who did just that.
item.title: #685: Larry vs. The IRS

item.description: Tariffs are stupid. This is one of the few things economists can agree on. Today, we bring you the story of the worst tariffs ever.
item.title: #833: Worst. Tariffs. Ever.

item.description: What happens when you put someone who wants to close an agency, in charge of that agency? Today on the show, we find out.
item.title: #832: Mulvaney Vs The CFPB

item.description: A man who got caught insider trading explains everything — what he did, how he did it, and why.
item.title: #671: An Insider Trader Tells All

item.description: Planet Money joins the gold rush 170 years late. And the rules are still about the same. How did that happen?
item.title: #831: The Golden Rules

item.description: What do sugar farmers have against candy? A lot, according to candy manufacturers.
item.title: #454: The Lollipop War

item.description: How did the social security number become the most important identifier in the United States? And is that even a good idea?
item.title: #830: XXX-XX-XXXX

item.description: Two guys from different ends of the political spectrum agree that the economy is rigged. And they think they know who's responsible.
item.title: #829: Rigging The Economy

item.description: There's something wrong with the way we're doing science. Today on the show, we find out how to fix it.
item.title: #677: The Experiment Experiment

item.description: We ponder the price of chicken, safe haven currencies, and the cash value of coupons. Why? Because you asked.
item.title: #828: You Asked For More

item.description: What do human blood, the conservative tax plan, and beer hops tell us about the world? Find out in today's episode.
item.title: #827: Three Indicators

item.description: Vodka is the best selling spirit in the United States, and there are zillions of brands. But is there any difference between them?
item.title: #826: The Vodka Proof

item.description: How do you reinvent something as simple as the wooden shipping pallet?
item.title: #545: The Blue Pallet

item.description: After a wildfire, teams of investigators start combing the wreckage for clues. Finding the cause means, maybe, finding someone to pay. But where's the line between a natural disaster and a human one?
item.title: #825: Who Started The Wildfire

item.description: If you can't beat 'em, send 'em a valentine.
item.title: #824: Our Valentines

item.description: Investors are pouring money into art, and a lot of it is disappearing into storage. We try to find out where the art goes, and why it goes there.
item.title: #823: Planet Monet

item.description: In 1978, a group of farmers in a Chinese village wrote a contract and hid it in the roof of a hut. They were afraid the document might get them executed. Instead, it transformed the Chinese economy.
item.title: #337: The Secret Document that Transformed China

item.description: How does the market for Super Bowl tickets work? And why did it collapse in 2015?
item.title: #822: The Shortest Super Bowl

item.description: Billionaires, diplomats, thinkfluencers. This is the Davos everyone hears about. Today on the show, we take you to a different Davos.
item.title: #821: The Other Davos

item.description: Phosphate is a crucial element, for farming, and for life. And there aren't too many places to get it. What if it runs out?
item.title: #820: P Is For Phosphorus

item.description: Douglas Bruce had a bold vision for Colorado.
item.title: #819: Tax Me If You Can

item.description: A biologist predicts a population bomb that will lead to global catastrophe. An economist sees a limitless future for mankind. The result is one of the most famous bets in economics.
item.title: #508: A Bet On The Future Of Humanity

item.description: The wild ginseng market has gone crazy. We go to a farm hidden in the Appalachian mountains to find out why.
item.title: #818: The Problem Of The Root

item.description: Will 3-D printing make gun control impossible?
item.title: #817: The Gun Man

item.description: Why does it take days to send money electronically?
item.title: #489: The Invisible Plumbing Of Our Economy

item.description: The bitcoin market has gone crazy. And it's revealing something strange. A lot of people can't find their bitcoins. We go looking for lost billions.
item.title: #816: Bitcoin Losers

item.description: What does a country with no debt look like? To find out, we went back to the United States in 1835.
item.title: #273: When The U.S. Paid Off The Entire National Debt

item.description: Each year, we take a cue from radio legend Paul Harvey and bring you "The Rest of the Story." We check in on some of the episodes that we've done in the past year, and tell you what's changed.
item.title: #815: The Rest of the Story 2017

item.description: David Kestenbaum noticed that a pack of Milk Chocolate M&M's weighs 1.69 ounces, but a pack of Peanut Butter M&M's weighs 1.63 ounces. He had to know why. But the confectionery world has its secrets.
item.title: #544: The M&M Anomaly

item.description: Congress just passed the largest tax overhaul in decades. We dig in.
item.title: #814: The Tax Plan Is Huge

item.description: Today on the show: A lawsuit over a Santa suit is a window into countless hidden fights that shape the stuff we buy. It's one man's battle against the U.S. government — and, in a way, against himself.
item.title: #670: The Santa Suit

item.description: Five reporters go to the New York Produce Show and Conference, each on a mission.
item.title: #813: The Produce Show

item.description: As a businessman, President Trump is known for his towering buildings. Today we tell the story of one of those skyscrapers and what it says about how and with whom Trump does business.
item.title: #812: High Rise, Low Returns

item.description: We've got a satellite. We got a rocket. We're heading to the launch pad.
item.title: SPACE 4: 3 2 1

item.description: We found a satellite. We tried to figure out what it would do. Now we need to choose our rocket.
item.title: SPACE 3: Rocket Shopping

item.description: We hitched a ride on a satellite. Now we have to figure out what we're going to do up there.
item.title: SPACE 2: Wait, Why Are We Going To Space?

item.description: We really are going to space.
item.title: SPACE 1: We're Going To Space

item.description: What did Paul Manafort do, exactly? Robert Mueller's indictment is 31 pages of hard-to-understand financial crime. We try to figure it out.
item.title: #807: Anatomy of a Hustle

item.description: A while back, the charity Feeding America was a mess. It was sending pickles to food banks that wanted produce, and potatoes to Idaho. So they called some economists, and a free food market was born.
item.title: #665: The Free Food Market

item.description: Walmart and Amazon are in a battle to be the store where you buy everything. But when both companies sell everything, what sets them apart? Food inventions like a bright, red pickle!
item.title: #806: Walmart's Pickle

item.description: In South Sudan, there is a kind of money that works even through bank failures and unstable governments. But when war struck, it upended a whole economy: the economy of cows.
item.title: #805: War And Peace And Cows

item.description: Once you've got a Birkin bag, you've made it. But to get one, you need more than just money. Birkins always seem to be mysteriously out of stock. This is no accident.
item.title: #672: Bagging the Birkin

item.description: Timothy Carpenter stole cell phones. Then his phone sold him out to the Feds. Now the Supreme Court has to decide how private our cell phone data should be.
item.title: #804: Your Cell Phone's A Snitch

item.description: Once a year, teenagers from across the country team up and compete to run the U.S. Federal Reserve.
item.title: #369: If Teens Ran the Fed

item.description: Why do smart people make dumb decisions? Figuring that out won Richard Thaler a Nobel Prize.
item.title: #803: Nudge, Nudge, Nobel

item.description: A Chinese company pays millions of dollars for a failing hotel in a small, rural town. We follow the trail of money, and it explains the world economy.
item.title: #802: The Hotel at the Center of the World

item.description: In any other industry, it's illegal for a group of companies to get together and cap wages. What makes the NCAA different?
item.title: #579: Is the NCAA An Illegal Cartel?

item.description: Today on the show: death. We have four stories about how people prepare for death and what they leave behind for the living.
item.title: #801: The Death Show

item.description: Bob Peterson claims to have found the thing people have sought for thousands of years — an investment guaranteed to double in value. He keeps it in a storage locker in Utah.
item.title: #581: Free Money

item.description: Capitalism isn't supposed to exist in North Korea. But small businesses are popping up, growing the nation's economy. And much of that money is going straight to the country's nuclear program.
item.title: #800: North Korea's Capitalists

item.description: Republicans are proposing big changes to the corporate income tax. Trillions of dollars are at stake. Here's what it all means.
item.title: #799: Corporate! Income! Tax!

item.description: For most of our lives, Equifax has been slurping up our financial data. Now the company's been hacked and our data is loose. Today, we trace this mess back to two brothers and one fateful decision.
item.title: #798: Bad Credit Bureau

item.description: It might just be the secret weapon of the U.S. economy.
item.title: #648: The Benefits of Bankruptcy

item.description: Bill Pennington's house floods a lot: Three times in the last three years. And every time his house floods, the government pays to help him repair the damage. Is something wrong here?
item.title: #797: Flood Money

item.description: The government suspended the Jones Act last week, to allow non-US ships to move fuel to victims of hurricanes in Houston and Florida. Which once again made us wonder why the act even exists.
item.title: #524: Mr Jones' Act

item.description: The basic income. A flat payment to citizens, without strings. Is it a progressive fantasy, or sensible policy? We may soon find out. The Finnish Government is testing it on 2,000 unemployed citizens.
item.title: #796: The Basic Income Experiment

item.description: The Guinness Book of World Records had a problem: It made its money selling books, but book sales aren't what they used to be. So Guinness changed what it was selling, and who they were selling it to.
item.title: #795: Is Record Breaking Broken?

item.description: Behind almost all popular music, there is this hidden economy of music producers buying and selling sonic snippets, texting each other half-finished beats, and angling for back-end royalties.
item.title: #794: How To Make It In The Music Business

item.description: Patty McCord helped create a workplace at Netflix that runs more like a professional sports team than a family. If you're not up to scratch, you're off the team. Is this the future of work?
item.title: #647: Hard Work Is Irrelevant

item.description: Congress has neglected to do the basic work of keeping the economy running. Today, we look at three time bombs they're sitting on: The federal budget, the debt ceiling, and DREAMers.
item.title: #793: This Week in Time Bombs

item.description: In the early 1960s, Tom Burrell became the first black man in Chicago advertising. He went on to change the whole industry, not just the way we think about ads, but the way advertisers think about us.
item.title: #628: This Ad's For You

item.description: When someone has been kidnapped, what do you do? If you pay ransom, you create a market for hostages. If you don't, people die. Different countries have different policies with different results.
item.title: #792: The Ransom Problem

item.description: There's an entire universe of things spies are not allowed to tell us. Today on the show, a few of the teeny things they can say. They might come in handy.
item.title: #791: Tips From Spies

item.description: Fake news from Russia helped spark a real war in Ukraine. What can Ukraine's fight against fake news teach the US?
item.title: #790: Rough Translation in Ukraine

item.description: Hidden in the trash heap of commerce there is buried treasure. Abandoned brands--including trusted, beloved brands--are waiting to be claimed and reborn. Today on the show: A cookie comeback.
item.title: #652: The Hydrox Resurrection

item.description: Your phone rings--it looks like your neighbor's calling. But instead, it's the creepiest scam of the year.
item.title: #789: Robocall Invasion

item.description: Costco made shopping harder, and customers loved it. Now a new company is taking the Costco experience to new extremes.
item.title: #653: The Anti-Store

item.description: When we go to the state fair, we don't go for the rides, deep-fried tacos or the butter cow. We head straight for the vendor marketplace to meet the masters of the lost art of salesmanship.
item.title: #788: Robert And Kenny Go To The Fair

item.description: We visit the workshop of the meat inventor who came up with Steak-Umm and KFC's popcorn chicken. And we try to figure out what meat inventors tell us about patents and innovation.
item.title: #399: Can You Patent a Steak?

item.description: Google just got hit with a multibillion-dollar antitrust fine. Here's what it tells us about competition, market power, and the biggest corporations on the planet.
item.title: #787: Google Is Big. Is That Bad?

item.description: We answer one of the most important questions in finance: What actually happens at the end of Trading Places?
item.title: #471: The Eddie Murphy Rule

item.description: News moves fast. Some of our best stories from this year have new chapters. Here, we catch up on three: Dirty trademarks, trading bots, and the war against the bald eagle.
item.title: #786: Rest of the Story 2017, Vol. 1

item.description: Sam Cohen buys stuff at big retail stores, then turns around and sells it on Amazon for a quick profit. It defies economic logic. But somehow, there's a whole multimillion-dollar industry doing this.
item.title: #629: Buy Low, Sell Prime

item.description: Most athlete endorsements make a product more expensive. But what happens when an NBA All-Star uses his name to make a sneaker much, much cheaper? On today's show: How that worked out.
item.title: #785: The Starbury

item.description: On today's show: The story of two guys who tried to cut the pay of a CEO at a small pneumatic tool company.
item.title: #594: Board Games

item.description: That meeting between Donald Trump Jr. and a Russian lawyer was two decades in the making. It began in 1996, when an adventurous American went to Russia, trying to make a buck.
item.title: #784: Meeting The Russians

item.description: Bail is broken. In New Jersey, defense attorneys, prosecutors, and judges banded together to try a dramatic solution: Blow it up.
item.title: #783: New Jersey Bails Out

item.description: We run through the entire federal budget — in 10 minutes. More than $6 billion per second. Go.
item.title: #782: Budget Time

item.description: We visit a company where people work on figuring out how to make stuff get cheaper.
item.title: #586: How Stuff Gets Cheaper

item.description: In Washington, D.C., there is a place where millions of dollars in ripped, burned, and water-soaked dollar bills are made new. On today's show, we get inside that room.
item.title: #781: The Money Fixers

item.description: We visited a libertarian summer paradise. What we found: People paying in gold. Exotic bacon dishes. A nine-year-old selling alcohol.
item.title: #286: Libertarian Summer Camp

item.description: Flip-floppers, this one's for you. Changing your mind is hard, but it's one of the smartest things you can do.
item.title: #780: On Second Thought

item.description: What happens when an unstoppable shrimp meets an unmovable senator? A researcher goes to Washington to defend herself, her shrimp, and science itself.
item.title: #779: Shrimp Fight Club

item.description: Qatar was on top of the world. Seemingly overnight, it became a pariah. On this episode, we drill into a rift years in the making: It's a tale of falcons, kidnapping, and a glowing Saudi Arabian orb.
item.title: #778: What the Falcon's Up With Qatar?

item.description: Today on the show, a businessman goes to prison, and decides he is going to disrupt the biggest captive market in America.
item.title: #610: The Prisoner's Solution

item.description: How a free-love commune embraced the free market and became a blockbuster brand.
item.title: #777: Free Love, Free Market

item.description: The president's budget promises 3% growth. Is that doable? Yes, but he won't like what it would take.
item.title: #776: Here We Grow Again

item.description: A battle with a weed divides neighbors and leads one farmer to shoot another dead. Today's show: The hunt for a better pesticide gets way out of hand.
item.title: #775: The Pigweed Killer

item.description: A man goes looking for the invisible wall that traps poor people in poverty. Finding it almost gets him killed.
item.title: #599: The Invisible Wall

item.description: You can name your business whatever you want. But the government won't register it as a trademark if it thinks it's offensive. It gets weird when you try to decide what is too offensive to trademark.
item.title: #774: Unspeakable Trademark

item.description: As long as there have been casinos, people have tried to cheat them. The latest attempt was by a group of hackers who tried to take down slot machines using math, iPhones, and a whole lot of swiping.
item.title: #773: Slot Flaw Scofflaws

item.description: How fast is the world really changing? The answer has implications for everything from how the next generation will live to whether robots really will take all our jobs.
item.title: #772: Small Change

item.description: The creation of the electronic spreadsheet transformed industries. But its effects ran deeper than that.
item.title: #606: Spreadsheets!

item.description: What happened when India's Prime Minister declared most of the paper money in India worthless? We travel to India to see what happened after the country's demonetization.
item.title: #771: When India's Cash Disappeared, Part Two

item.description: Something incredible happened in India about six months ago. The government declared most of the paper money invalid. Demonetization they called it. Today, we meet the man who came up with the plan.
item.title: #770: When India's Cash Disappeared, Part One

item.description: We visit a job market created by economists, for economists. It's a hyper-efficient, optimized system, tested by game theorists, tweaked by a Nobel Prize winner, but it requires comfortable shoes.
item.title: #769: Speed Dating For Economists

item.description: Ten years ago, two little-known hedge funds blew up, and the financial crisis was on its way. Today, we ask the person at the center of it all, former Fed Chairman Ben Bernanke, why it happened.
item.title: #768: A Chat With Ben Bernanke

item.description: Today on the show, how a New Hampshire hotel filled with boozing economists saved the global economy.
item.title: #553: The Dollar At The Center Of The World

item.description: In 1838, the Maryland Jesuits sold 272 people, slaves, to pay the debts of Georgetown University. We talk with the descendants about what - if anything - they're owed.
item.title: #767: Georgetown, Louisiana, Part Two

item.description: For the residents of a small Louisiana town, there's always been a question about their past: How'd they get there? Solving the mystery only raised more questions.
item.title: #766: Georgetown, Louisiana, Part One

item.description: Where do holidays like National Potato Chip Day and Argyle Day come from? We trace the roots of one made-up holiday until we find out who is running the global holiday machine.
item.title: #765: The Holiday Industrial Complex

item.description: One in three American jobs require a license. Today on the show, why those licensing rules hurt the U.S. economy.
item.title: #381: When Business Loves Regulation

item.description: One man figured out how to reproduce the magic of an Irish pub, and ship it in a container to anywhere in the world.
item.title: #764: Pub In A Box

item.description: On today's show, we get in on the future of investing. We build an automated stock-trading bot. It analyzes the twitter feed of President Donald Trump, then trades stocks with real money. Our money.
item.title: #763: BOTUS

item.description: On today's show: Snuggies, printer toner, and a banking road trip. Three stories about what happens when you actually read the fine print.
item.title: #762: The Fine Print

item.description: Jason Blum makes a lot of movies and makes them cheap. So why are so many turning into blockbusters?
item.title: #650: The Business Genius Behind Get Out

item.description: A populist president versus the most powerful banker in America.
item.title: #761: The Bank War

item.description: One professor had a way to make filing taxes easy and painless. It worked. People loved it. But then a big tax lobby heard about it...
item.title: #760: Tax Hero

item.description: Three short stories about putting a price on something hard to value precisely. We go from $4.66 under a pillow all the way up to $1 trillion across every inch of highway in America
item.title: #759: What's It Worth To You?

item.description: A hundred years ago, nobody talked about "the economy." That's because easy ways to measure and talk about it hadn't been invented. On today's show: how we started boiling nations down to a number.
item.title: #522: The Invention Of 'The Economy'

item.description: The Constitution contains a paragraph known as the Emoluments Clause. It's 49 words meant to prevent foreign influence on US officials. How does it apply to a president with a global business empire?
item.title: #758: Can Trump Take The Money?

item.description: Wikileaks released documents listing the hacks the CIA uses to spy on people. So we revisit our story on hackers for hire: people hunting for flaws in your phone to sell to people, or even the CIA.
item.title: #596: Hacking The iPhone For Fun, Profit, And Maybe Espionage

item.description: President Trump does not like Dodd-Frank, the 2010 law that transformed banking regulation. On today's show, we ask: What are the key parts of the law? And how are they likely to change?
item.title: #757: Strong Feelings About Dodd-Frank

item.description: Here at Planet Money, we often wonder: how useful is economics in our everyday lives? Could the principles of economics be applied to the most intimate of human experiences, like, say, love?
item.title: #513: Dear Economist, I Need A Date

item.description: Early every year, 30 billion bees make their way across the country to California's Central Valley. Here's why.
item.title: #756: The Bees Go To California

item.description: In the span of a few months in 1980, more than 100,000 Cuban immigrants arrived in Miami. So what happened to Florida's economy with all these new people coming in? And what can we learn from it?
item.title: #654: When The Boats Arrive

item.description: A charismatic populist president wanted to boost manufacturing and create jobs. She told companies, 'if you want to sell your stuff here, you have to build it here.' This is what happened.
item.title: #755: The Phone At The End Of The World

item.description: Here at Planet Money, our favorite stories are the ones we wish we'd done ourselves. On the show, we call out rivals and colleagues who did what we try to do better than we could have done it.
item.title: #754: I'm So Happy For You!

item.description: Charlie Shrem went to prison. While he was there, he thought up a better way to move money behind bars. Now, he's out and trying to sell his idea to international investors.
item.title: #753: Blockchain Gang

item.description: What would the perfect immigration system look like? We ask three economists and get three very different answers. (None of which include building a wall.)
item.title: #436: If Economists Controlled The Borders

item.description: Picture an organic farm, with thousands of free-range chickens roaming wide-open land. Now picture it from above, from the vantage of a soaring bald eagle. It's an all-you-can-eat buffet.
item.title: #752: Eagles vs. Chickens

item.description: Over the next few months, we're going to explain President Trump's economic plans. Today: a totally new idea for corporate taxes. What's the plan, what's the theory behind it, and does it work?
item.title: #751: The Thing About That Border Tax

item.description: When an American loses his/her job to trade, there's program to help. It's been around for decades. It makes a lot of sense. It is a generous program. And almost nobody's heard of it. But why?
item.title: #750: Retraining Day

item.description: President Trump talks about putting tariffs on foreign cars. But there are already tariffs on auto imports and one got there because of chickens in Germany. This is how trade barriers tend to spread.
item.title: #632: The Chicken Tax

item.description: Ed Thorp started his career teaching math at MIT. Then he slid sideways into blackjack, changed the game forever, and set his sights on Wall Street investing. He changed that forever too.
item.title: #749: Professor Blackjack

item.description: Congress writes laws, but the president makes the rules that put the laws in action. President Obama's staff has been scrambling to lock in rules before Trump takes the helm. But will they stick?
item.title: #748: Undoing Obama

item.description: When Steve Flatow's daughter was killed in a terror attack, he wanted someone to pay. His target was the Iranian government. His quest would pit him against both Iran and the White House.
item.title: #747: The Man Who Sued Iran

item.description: A Republican governor lives the dream. He cuts taxes dramatically in his state and he promises good times ahead. But the good times do not come.
item.title: #577: The Kansas Experiment

item.description: Wall Street traders and Las Vegas gamblers have a lot in common. But when a Wall Street firm set up shop taking Vegas bets, both sides got a surprise.
item.title: #746: Wall Street Goes To Vegas

item.description: People are talking about how the Dow Jones Industrial Average is about to hit a new record: Twenty thousand. We have a pretty strong opinion about the Dow. We think you should ignore it.
item.title: #443: Don't Believe The Hype

item.description: It's time for an annual Planet Money tradition--we revisit some of our favorite stories from the past year, and see what's changed since we turned off our mics.
item.title: #745: The Rest Of The Story, 2016 Edition

item.description: The man who ran the last bank bailout has a plan to prevent the next one.
item.title: #744: The Last Bank Bailout

item.description: There's an idea that dates back at least to biblical times. That there should be a moment when debts are forgiven. Its called a jubilee. One country tried it.
item.title: #587: Jubilee! (?)

item.description: Today on the show, two unions separated by 200 years, an ocean and an exit clause. The United States has no exit clause. It led to civil war. Europe, on the other hand, has Article 50.
item.title: #743: 50 Ways to Leave Your Union

item.description: On today's show, how a band of medieval warrior monks sworn to poverty got into the banking business and changed the way we think about money forever.
item.title: #742: Making Bank

item.description: A special holiday episode about the epic, decades-long feud between the two companies that make just about every handbell in the world.
item.title: #592: Bell Wars

item.description: The story of a court case. On one side, the best lawyers money can buy. On the other, a night school lawyer who had never argued a case before. The outcome could affect everyone on the Internet.
item.title: #741: Amy and Steve vs. Facebook

item.description: All types of companies are struggling with burnout. Many try to fix it. Most of them fail. One exception: A 26-year-old call center manager, with stress balls and costumes in her arsenal.
item.title: #740: Burnout

item.description: We track down a fake-news creator in the suburbs, uncover his empire of fake-news sites, and get him to tell us his secrets.
item.title: #739: Finding The Fake-News King

item.description: In this show: How we got from candles made out of cow fat to as much light as we want. The history of light is the history of economic growth — of things getting faster, cheaper, and more efficient.
item.title: #534: The History Of Light

item.description: Russia's latest ambition: To build a steak empire. On today's show, a fourth-generation American cowboy teaches Russian ranchers how to make American-style steaks. Some things get lost in translation.
item.title: #738: The Russian Rodeo

item.description: We go on a madcap dash through discounts, bargains and tough tradeoffs. Like the headline says: We bring you stories of 17 deals in just 17 minutes (not counting the intro, the ad, or the credits).
item.title: #737: 17 Deals In 17 Minutes

item.description: What happens when a creativity guru meets the winner of this year's Nobel Memorial Prize in economics? You get life lessons in making art, and negotiating contracts.
item.title: #736: Messy Nobel

item.description: The story of a guy who tried to make something of himself by getting into a rough business. And the story of a time when the world went wild for debt.
item.title: #574: The Buffalo Talk-Off

item.description: Candidates promise all kinds of things. But once they get into office, it's not always possible to carry through on them. We ask, can Trump do the things he's pledged to do?
item.title: #735: President Trump

item.description: Donald Trump is our president elect. We look at three economic indicators to see what they can tell us about a Trump presidency.
item.title: #734: The Trump Indicators

item.description: Truffles are a lumpy, smelly fungus. They're also one of the most coveted foods in the world. Why are they so expensive? And why are people willing to pay so much for them?
item.title: #733: A Trunk Full of Truffles

item.description: On today's show, Planet Money's economist-approved fake candidate makes his first ads. Then we nervously watch to see what a focus group thinks of them.
item.title: #413: Our Fake Candidate Meets The People

item.description: Banks like Wells Fargo have a weapon that can destroy an employee's career: A form. A long, boring form most people don't even know exists.
item.title: #732: Bad Form, Wells Fargo

item.description: Behold the Planet Money economic platform, crafted by brilliant economists of all stripes, and pure poison to any politician who embraces it.
item.title: #387: The No-Brainer Economic Platform

item.description: Venezuela has just about every economic advantage a country could ask for: fertile land, good climate, educated population, and oil, lots and lots of oil. So how did it go so wrong?
item.title: #731: How Venezuela Imploded

item.description: A doctor treating psychiatric patients in an emergency room created the first self-checkout machine in his spare time. Now he can't stand self checkout. So we take him shopping.
item.title: #730: Self Checkout

item.description: Subaru's sales had been slumping for years. So the car company took a big risk and targeted a group of consumers that just about everyone else was ignoring.
item.title: #729: When Subaru Came Out

item.description: How we got from mealy, nasty apples to apples that taste delicious. The story starts with a breeder who discovered a miracle apple. But discovering that apple wasn't enough.
item.title: #627: The Miracle Apple

item.description: We take you inside the headquarters of Wells Fargo bank. It's a place where a bunch of young, stressed-out workers were rewarded for doing some very bad things.
item.title: #728: The Wells Fargo Hustle

item.description: On today's episode, we'll take you to a place where dying has become acceptable dinner conversation. A place that also happens to have the lowest healthcare spending of any region in the country.
item.title: #521: The Town That Loves Death

item.description: New show! You asked us questions about the economy and oddities in your world. We answer.
item.title: #727: You Asked For It, Again

item.description: We made an audio glossary for the confusing economic jargon that came up during the first presidential debate.
item.title: #726: Terms of the Debate

item.description: On today's show: The fight over free trade. Come for the man who dreamed of world peace through trade. Stay for Robert Smith in the mean streets of Seattle.
item.title: #725: Trade Show

item.description: We test two competing theories, from a food writer and an economist. Are customers being forced to walk through the store or is it just practical to keep the milk at the back?
item.title: #555: Why Is The Milk In The Back Of The Store?

item.description: Prices of new textbooks have been going up like crazy — faster than food, cars, even healthcare. On today's show: Why textbooks have gotten so expensive.
item.title: #573: Why Textbook Prices Keep Climbing

item.description: The internet was supposed to get rid of middlemen--but instead they are taking over the global economy.
item.title: #724: Cat Scam

item.description: If you're a zoo or aquarium and you want a new animal, you don't use money to get it. You have to find another way. In this episode, we investigate: How many mackerel is a flock of puffins worth?
item.title: #566: The Zoo Economy

item.description: There is a mystery in many poor countries. Why don't farmers specialize and grow more food? Two economists with very different theories go head to head to find out.
item.title: #723: The Risk Farmers

item.description: For decades, most websites ended in either .com, .net, or .org. But a few years ago, everything changed.
item.title: #532: The Wild West Of The Internet

item.description: One telenovela actress-turned-executive decided to create a new kind of drama. Her work changed the landscape of Spanish language TV--and of all TV.
item.title: #722: The New Telenovela

item.description: Why is it so hard to knock down 17 vacant houses in a shrinking city?
item.title: #721: Unbuilding A City

item.description: Last of five episodes. We follow the Planet Money oil to a gas station. And we ask: What would our world look like if there were no fossil fuels?
item.title: Oil #5: Imagine A World Without Oil

item.description: Fourth of five episodes. Oil is in our sneakers, our clothes, and the computer or phone you're using right now. On today's show: The story of the man who made it happen.
item.title: Oil #4: How Oil Got Into Everything

item.description: Third of five episodes. The Planet Money oil faces a test, we sell it, and we meet the man who set off the fracking boom in America.
item.title: Oil #3: How Fracking Changed the World

item.description: Second of five episodes. Oil is priced down to the penny, and the price changes every day. Who sets that price?
item.title: Oil #2: The Price Of Oil

item.description: We're getting into the oil business. We go to Kansas, and negotiate with a preacher to buy 100 barrels of crude.
item.title: Oil #1: We Buy Oil

item.description: There's an obscure law that governs just about anything that travels by ship in the U.S. — bananas, hairdryers, gasoline, even people. Economists do not like it. But it just won't go away.
item.title: #524: Mr Jones' Act

item.description: Building a robot that can sew even simple clothes is surprisingly hard. A retired professor in Atlanta thinks he's solved the problem. It could bring clothing manufacturing back to America.
item.title: #715: The Sewing Robot

item.description: The computer or phone that you use knows a lot about you. It knows your secrets — and it might be giving them away.
item.title: #548: Project Eavesdrop

item.description: Crafting a TV game show is a balancing act. Producers have to carefully calibrate the rules, the drama and the prizes just right. Sometimes they get it way wrong.
item.title: #714: Can A Game Show Lose?

item.description: A lot of computing pioneers were women. For decades, the number of women in computer science was growing. But in 1984, something changed.
item.title: #576: When Women Stopped Coding

item.description: A tale of violence, payback, and how to make things right.
item.title: #713: Paying for the Crime

item.description: Three stories of people getting their money back — or trying to. From a hospital, a scammer, and the ever-exciting global bond market.
item.title: #712: I Want My Money Back

item.description: Scoring a fix is cheap and today's heroin is strong. But that's just part of the reason why America got hooked. Today on the show, we trace the roots of America's heroin epidemic.
item.title: #711: Hooked on Heroin

item.description: Brexit is like a breakup. So today a divorce story in two acts. We hear from both sides: The people who voted to leave, and the Europeans being left.
item.title: #710: The Brexit Break-Up

item.description: Where is the line between being inspired by somebody's creative work and stealing it?
item.title: #709: The Quiet Old Lady Who Whispers "Fair Use"

item.description: Bitcoin was supposed to revolutionize the way money works. But the thing people love about it may be destroying it.
item.title: #708: Bitcoin Divided

item.description: What just happened in the UK? And what's coming next?
item.title: #707: Brexit

item.description: How much of a brand is real? How much is in our heads?
item.title: #538: Is A Stradivarius Just A Violin?

item.description: If your country's main export is water, what happens when your wells run dry?
item.title: #706: Water's Worth

item.description: There is a crime wave in the West right now. Cattle rustling — stealing cattle — is on the rise. The crime is as old as America, and it's making a big comeback.
item.title: #583: Cow Noir

item.description: Two bodybuilders go at it over a Stanford University patent. And we dive in to make sense of it.
item.title: #705: The Muscle Patents

item.description: Technology means that no matter what job you have — whether you're alone in a truck on an empty road or sitting in a cubicle in front of a computer — your company can now track everything you do.
item.title: #536: The Future Of Work Looks Like A UPS Truck

item.description: This episode is for everyone who's ever had to ask their coworkers to quiet down or walk laps of the office to make a private phone call. Today on the show: We meet the man who stole your office door.
item.title: #704: Open Office

item.description: It's something you can see on every day and on every block in most major cities. But in Myanmar, a country that was cut off from the rest of the world for decades, an ATM is a small miracle.
item.title: #463: How To Get A Country To Trust Its Banks

item.description: How do you secretly stash away a million dollars? One way is to hide the money in plain sight, right in the heart of New York City. Today's show: the case of who owns Apartment 5B.
item.title: #703: How To Hide A Million Dollars In Plain Sight

item.description: Meet a single mother who makes $16,000 a year and managed to fund a vacation at a Caribbean resort with an interest-free loan from one of the world's largest banks.
item.title: #217: The Art Of Living At The Poverty Line

item.description: One night, Lariat Alhassan heard an ad on the radio. It said the Nigerian government was offering millions of dollars to people with business ideas, practically no strings attached. She gave it a go.
item.title: #702: Nigeria, You Win!

item.description: In New York City, more than 5,000 food trucks and carts compete for the business of hungry office workers. And finding the right spot to set up shop can mean the difference between fortune and ruin.
item.title: #366: How To Make It In The Food Truck Business

item.description: To serve Muslim customers, a bank in Michigan tried to comply with both U.S. regulations and Islamic law. One problem: Islamic law prohibits charging interest.
item.title: #701: A Bank Without Interest

item.description: On today's show, we open up some of those annoying pharmaceutical spam emails and find out who's clicking to buy herbal viagra? Also, what happens when they do?
item.title: #430: Black Market Pharmacies And The Spam Empire Behind Them

item.description: Beer. Water. Pretzels. It takes effort, strategy, and some serious lungs to sell expensive junk food at a baseball game. Meet the hot dog vending legend of Fenway Park.
item.title: #700: Peanuts and Cracker Jack

item.description: To get to the other side...where there are millions of dollars in tax breaks.
item.title: #699: Why Did The Job Cross The Road?

item.description: Housing subsidies are often given out through a lottery. But why do we let random chance decide who gets help with the rent? We don't do that for food stamps or health care, so why housing?
item.title: #698: The Long Way Home

item.description: In this episode, we consider a world where everybody cheats, and where you can't win unless you game the regulators: Professional cycling.
item.title: #417: Lance Armstrong and The Business of Doping

item.description: When you're an employer looking at a giant stack of resumes, you have to find some way to quickly narrow the field. How do you do that fairly? And what happens when your good intentions backfire?
item.title: #697: Help Wanted

item.description: We talk to Kid Rock about how he tried to cut scalpers out of the business — and still sell cheap tickets to his shows.
item.title: #468: Kid Rock Vs. The Scalpers

item.description: The modern class action was created on a typewriter in the back of a car. (Sort of.) Now, thousands of these lawsuits are filed every year. How did we get here? Is this really a good way to do things?
item.title: #696: Class Action

item.description: Credit cards with chips in them have been around for four decades. So why is America only getting them now? And now that they are here, why are so few places using them?
item.title: #695: Put A Chip On It

item.description: Imagine a safer kind of gun. Imagine a company with a plan to build it. Imagine customers ready to buy it. Imagine what could go wrong. A whole lot.
item.title: #694: The Gun That Wouldn't Shoot

item.description: A California mall straddles the border between two cities — and the minimum wage is higher on one side.
item.title: #562: A Mall Divided

item.description: Puerto Rico is part of the United States, but not one of the United States. And this limbo status has brought a world of economic trouble.
item.title: #693: Unpayable

item.description: And how can we meet our fake shareholder and fake director?
item.title: #403: What Can We Do With Our Shell Companies?

item.description: On today's show, we tell the stories of a few mysterious lines on IRS form 1040 — the basic tax form. In its own, maddening way, the 1040 is a great American document.
item.title: #692: The Secret Life Of Line 24

item.description: There's a revolution underway in the world of cable TV--more and more people are getting rid of it. And there are some unforeseen consequences when we cut the cord and go our separate ways.
item.title: #691: The Great Unbundling

item.description: We talk to a professional poker player who lost on the first day of poker's most famous tournament--but went on to get a huge payout. Turns out there's a game behind the game.
item.title: #690: All In

item.description: In this show, we dive deep into the world of hiding money. We look for the easiest place to shelter a bank account and set up our own shell company in an offshore tax haven. Good times.
item.title: #390: We Set Up An Offshore Company In A Tax Haven
